before painting any foam terrain I
always do a coat of my Mod Podge and black paint mixture to harden protect
and prime the foam a lot of people seem really concerned about this step
obscuring detail but the only way that happens is if you apply if poorly
I don't water down my mixture but I do apply it with a wet brush this small
amount of water on the brush is enough to dilute the mixture and ensure it gets
into all the small nooks and crannies the real trick is to make sure you
completely spread out any excess you only want a very thin coating and over
brushing until there is absolutely no excess no pooling or globs of Mod Podge
is key if you apply it carefully and properly you will not lose any detail
even the finest indents and textures in the foam will be preserved it's also
really important that you let this coating fully dry before moving on to
paint for the base coat I use a medium tan color specifically here it's tan by
craft smart using a tan rather than a grey that is simply a mixture of white
and black will look a lot more realistic by adding some warm brown undertones to
the piece like the Mod Podge it's important to get a full thin coverage
without any excess paint left behind it's okay if this code is a little
uneven with some of the black showing through as this will add some variance
to the piece I do a second coat immediately after the first while
everything is still damp letting it dry completely before doing a second coat is
unnecessary and it will actually remove some of the desired variation in depth
of color as it will cover better if the first coat is totally dry
you'll also notice that I get this base color into all of the grout lines some
people try to preserve the black primer in the low spots while painting but that
will give you a very subpar result it's much better to cover everything
completely and let the wash steps later enhance those grout lines a key detail
to making stonework more visually interesting is adding subtle differences
from brick to brick using two secondary colors in this case craft smarts gray
and golden brown I randomly pick out some bricks to individually paint
different colors there's no rule as to how many you do or which ones you do but
in general I keep about 40 to 50 percent of the bricks the main base color and
the rest a combination of these other colors I also do a few with a mixed
blend of the base coat and secondary colors for even more variation an
important thing to keep in mind at this step is that it's okay that it looks
almost cartoonish in its a variety of color these will all be cohesive with
the dry brushing later and much more subdued by the washers once happy with
the secondary colors it's time for dry brushing to pick up the edge details I
do two stages here the first stage I use a lighter tan here it's called suede by
craft smart you want to be very sparing with this pretty much remove all excess
paint from the brush and apply very lightly an important tip is that you use
a clean dry brush for this step if your brush is even slightly damp from washing
it out you will end up with a smearing effect that is really undesirable
I also do the second dry brushing using
a plain white I'm really really light handed with this I only want the
smallest high points picking it up I also do all the white dry brushing from
the same direction of top down this is to help indicate a light source this is
a subtle effect but I believe it helps sell the paint job and it really doesn't
require much extra effort to implement
now the part of the paint job that really does most of the heavy lifting
are the washes you can just do a basic black wash but I prefer to do a
combination for a more diverse look I start with my basic black wash I have a
video on how to make this that I'll link at the top of the screen I often find it
easiest to just pour some wash right onto the piece and spread it carefully
with a clean brush you want to avoid pressing too hard so you don't rehydrate
and smear your paint the black wash is the one that subdues the colors and
enhances all the grout lines but I also like to add a brown wash to give some
more color and grime to the stone last I will often add some green wash sparingly
to give a subtle mildew effect depending on your piece you can either let it dry
flat so that gravity takes the wash to the lowest points or you can let it
drive vertically to create a bit of a streaking effect both have their
advantages and disadvantages and really the size and shape of the piece usually
dictates how you let it dry
as you can see putting a little more effort and thought into painting stone
